Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Atomically Thin, Layered, and 2D Non-Carbon Materials and Systems. To Be Held in Boston, November 26 to December 1,2017.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The Symposium NM4: Atomically Thin, Layered, and 2D Non-Carbon Materials and Systems? will take place from November 26 to December 1, 2017 at the Hynes Convention Center and Boston Sheraton Hotel in Boston, MA. Topics to be addressed include two-dimensional (2D) materials and devices, the latest developments in science and engineering and advances in the material and device applications with non-carbon 2D materials. The Symposium seeks financial support to support student and junior researcher participation, as well as invited speakers. It will host world-renowned scientists in the area of two-dimensional (2D) materials science and technology as invited speakers, whose expertise range from synthesis, characterizations, device development, theory and applications. There will be a vigorous exchange of new ideas on device and fabrication technology, and a huge opportunity to initiate and strengthen national and international collaboration, which will be of enormous benefit to students and young scholars in their pursuit of high-quality research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposed project was to organize a scientific symposium entitled, Symposium NM4: Atomically Thin, Layered, and 2D Non-Carbon Materials and Systems, which focused on the science and technology of atomically thin (2D) materials, including topics that emphasized device development and applications of these materials. The symposium was held under the auspices of the Materials Research Society at the MRS Fall 2017 meeting held in Boston, MA.

The presented symposium topic has arguably remained one of the fastest-growing research areas of the past few years, represented by the innumerable publications at extremely high impact and high-visibility journals worldwide. For experts and young scholars alike, this symposium provided an incredible opportunity to become familiar and involved in the breathtaking new developments in this field. As in the past, this symposium generated one of the largest audiences in the Fall meeting, giving young scholars an unprecedented opportunity to immerse themselves in one of most rapidly growing and impactful fields of contemporary science. Through dissemination of state-of-the-art research in 2D materials and devices, the symposium will showcased the latest developments in science and engineering. This is expected to promote rapid advances in the material and device applications with non-carbon 2D materials, vigorous exchange of new ideas on device and fabrication technology, and provide a huge opportunity to initiate and strengthen national and international collaborations, which are enormous benefits to students and young scholars in their pursuit of high-quality research. The symposium has taken proactive steps for minority involvement and diversity in its organizational structure, invited speakers list, and through requested support for various under-represented groups.
